_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Don Miguel Mexican Foods, Inc., which has no parent company, and therefore no parent company Dun &  Bradstreet number (item 1.4.6), processes fine, frozen foods. Don Miguel has not been assigned an EPA Facility Identifier nor another EPA Systems Facility I.D. (items 1.3 & 1.2)  The cooling and freezing of the food product is accomplished by the refrigeration system which utilizes anhydrous ammonia as the primary refrigerant. The system is defined as a closed loop "Direct" type system.

Don Miguel Mexican Foods, Inc. has developed a risk management program according to EPA's Risk Management Program regulation (40 CFR Part 68) and to address California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4, Sections 2735-2785) to enhance already existing safety and emergency action programs. Don Miguel is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Don Miguel?s staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using ammonia as a refrigerant.

Don Miguel Mexican Foods, Inc. has two distinct and separate ammonia systems. These systems are located at opposite ends of the facility with sufficient separation to ensure that an emergency at one system would not affect the other. System #1 (Frick System) contains approximately 12209 lbs of ammonia, which surpasses the federal threshold quantity of 10000 lbs and CalARP threshold quantity of 500 lbs. System #2 (Frigo System) contains approximately 2500 lbs of ammonia, which surpasses the CalARP threshold quantity of 500 lbs.  The Frick System and the Frigo System are both included in this report.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Don Miguel facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources inv

ested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Refrigeration Systems. Don Miguel's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The ammonia systems are composed of the following key components:

Frick System:
-Four Compressors
-Nine Pressure Vessels
-Two Purgers
-Two Condensers
-Eighteen Evaporators
-Relief valves, hand valves, solinoid valves, check valves, level switches, expansion valves and pressure regulators.
-Piping and other ancillary equipment.
-Hot gas and water defrost piping and automatic controller.
-Fire Department Emergency Dump, Valve Station

Frigo System
-Two Compressors
-Two Condensers
-Four Pressure Vessels
-One Purgers
-One Evaporator
-Relief valves, hand valves, solinoid valves, check valves, level switches, expansion valves and pressure regulators.
-Piping and other ancillary equipment.
-Water Defrost System

System operation cycle begins at the high pressure receiver where liquid ammonia is fed to the pump accumulators.  At this point the ammonia flashes down to saturation temperature prior to being pumped to the evaporators. Liquid vapor mixture is returned to the accumulator from the evaporators where the gas is separated from the liquid. The gas is then drawn to the compressor where it is compressed and the pressure is increased to condensing pressure. The superheated compressor discharge travels to the evaporative condenser where the ammonia gas gives up its heat and is condensed to a liquid and returned to the high pressure receiver to begin the cycle once again.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description:Per the RMP and CalARP regulations one worst case analysis has been defined as a release of the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored in the larges

t equipment item (given that the Ammonia Refrigeration System is comprised of interconnected equipment) ? 2,800 pounds in 10 minutes. Only one worst case scenario is given as this represents the worst case from either of the two systems. Although there are numerous controls to prevent such a release and to manage its consequences, portions of the Ammonia Refrigeration System are located outside, and therefore, no credit for administrative controls or passive mitigation features was taken for the worst-case release scenario.  The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used, as specified by the RMP and CalARP regulations.  The EPA?s RMP*Comp Dispersion Modeling Software and the publicly available SLAB Dispersion Modeling Software were used to determine the maximum downwind endpoint distance to 200 ppm.  The results show that off-site areas may be affected including Edison Field.  RMP*Comp was used to benchmark the results, and the final endpoint distances were calculated using SLAB to provide more accurate, yet still ?conservative?, results. This WCS is highly unlikly to occur because of active mitagation measures that can be taken and weather conditions that are unlikly as well.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description:A more realistic alternative release scenario was modeled as a release of anhydrous ammonia liquid as a result of an ammonia transfer hose failure for 1 minute.  For this alternative release scenario, the total quantity of ammonia calculated to be released is 50 pounds. This ARS was developed by the  team looked at the process hazard analysis, the five year accident history and the history of incidents for similar facilities throughout the industry.

The meteorological conditions specified by regulation for alternative release scenarios were used, except for wind speed (3.5 m/s) which represents local conditions  accurately. The EPA?s RMP*Comp Dispersion Modeling Software and the SLAB Dispersion Modeling Software were

used to determine the maximum downwind endpoint distance to 200 ppm.  The downwind distance for this alternative release scenario is significantly less than that for the worst-case scenario.  Although off-site areas may also be affected for this alternative release scenario, the maximum endpoint distance for this alternative release scenario is just beyond the Don Miguel Facility perimeter. Therefore members of the general public are unlikly to be affected.

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; the Don Miguel Facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make this type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent.  Turbulence causes entertainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:
- There are process valves to permit isolation of any leaks in place.
- Diking and floor drains in the Engine Room would provide containment for liquid release and therefore minimize the potential for offsite impact.
- Although portions of the Ammonia Refrigeration System are outside the Engine Room, at any particular time, a large fraction of the ammonia is located in the Engine Room.  Conservatively, no credit for enclosure mitigation was taken.
-

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by plant personnel, as necessary.
- The history of the Don Miguel Facility (i.e., no CalARP-applicable ammonia releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Ammonia Refrigeration System.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIEC PREVENTION STEPS

As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were implemented by Don Miguel to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia for refrigeration.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  The CalARP Prevention Program elements include:
- Employee Involvement
- Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
- Operating Procedures
- Employee Training
- Pre-Startup Safety Review
- Mechanical Integrity
- Hot Work Permit
- Management of Change
- Incident Investigation
- Emergency Planning and Response
- Compliance Audits   
- Process Safety Information
- Contractors
- Trade Secrets
Under Management of Change (item 7.8a) there has not been a requirement for a management of change procedure as of this date, therefore there is no date listed in this item: Pre-startup safety review (item 7.9): as of this date there has not been a requirement for a pre-startup safety review, therefore this item was left blank. Compliance Audits (items 7.10 a&b) a compliance audit has not been required for this facility as of this date therefore the date for this item was left blank.  Incident Investigation (item 7.11 a&b): as of this date there have been no incidents to investigate, therefore the date for this item is blank.
In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Business Emergegency Plan. See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of ammonia at the Don Miguel Facility in at least the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Don Miguel has filed a Chemical Inventory Business Emergency Plan with the Anaheim Fire Department and this plan includes:
-Emergency alarm proceedures.
-Evacuation procedures
-Safety and health considerations.
-Notification procedures.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Several studies have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the Don Miguel Facility.  These studies include the following:  Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Seismic Assessment, and Hazard Assessment.  Any outstanding recommendations from these studies will have been implemented by December 31, 2003.

EXTERNAL EVENTS ASSESSMENT

General External Events

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4, Section 2745.7(q), the following general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of ammonia were addressed by the January 2003, ?Process Hazard Analysis ? Ammonia Refrigeration Systems?.  In consultation with the AA, Don Miguel determined that with the exception of seismic events, scope and magnitude were not applicable to the external events discussions.
 - Earthquakes
 - Expansive Soils, Slope Stability, Regional Subsidence
 - High Winds
 - Floods
 - Lightning
 - Sabotage
 - Sources of Fires
 - Railroads
 - Highways

Seismic Assessment

Background information, the analysis, and the results are documented in the "Don Miguel Mexican Foods, Inc. Ammonia. System Seismic Assessment, Rev. 0".  The contents of this Seismic Assessment include:
 - Introduction
 - Significant Seismic Sources
 - Ground Shaking Hazard
 - Additional Seismic Hazards
 - Engineering Evaluation
 - Experience

Results and Conclusions are identified in the report body.

Earthquake Threat

The significant seismic sources for the facility are the Newport-Inglewood fault 17 km to the south and the Whittier Faullt 15 km to the north. These faults are both capable of producing earthquakes of a 7.0 magnitude.  T

he estimated largest mean peak ground acceleration, which should be used for design at the site is 0.44g based on the 1997 Uniform Building Code (UBC) parameters. In the absence of a soils report for the site, a soil profile Type SD is assumed. The seismic assessment described in this report, which was performed for the existing equipment and their supports, was based on this UBC demand earthquake.  Any recommended modifications to the equipment and supports for seismic concerns should also meet this demand acceleration and its related seismic effects.
 - No known fault trace transects the site, and therefore the potential for fault rupture at the site is remote.  Evaluation of the site for liquefaction potential would require a more detailed assessment of the characteristics of the soils underlying the facility.
 - The potential for landslides due to seismic activity affecting the facility site is low, since the site has negligible topographic relief and is not located in a hillside area.
 - The site is located more than 10 miles inland from the coast so the potential for tsunami inundation at the site is highly unlikely.
